Award.AwardTitle: Interactions between Commutative Algebra and Algebraic Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The "Interactions between Commutative Algebra and Algebraic Geometry" conference will be held at Queen's University in Kingston, Ontario, Canada, October 20-21, 2012, as a special edition of the Route 81 conference series that has rotated annually among Cornell University, Queen's University, and Syracuse University for over two decades. This conference will bring together leading experts, young researchers, recent Ph.D.s and graduate students in Commutative Algebra and Algebraic Geometry from across the United States and Canada and from around the world. The topics of focus are secant varieties, properties of fat points, and homological invariants.

The conference will highlight many aspects of the strong interplay that exists between Algebraic Geometry and Commutative Algebra in the focus areas mentioned above, enabling participants to gain a better understanding of current research and recent advances on these topics. By providing travel and lodging support for US-based participants, this grant will promote the career development of graduate students and early career researchers from the US by bringing them into contact both with peers and with leading experts from the US, Canada and abroad, in an exciting atmosphere of intellectual engagement designed to stimulate the exchange of ideas and to foster research collaborations among the participants. Further details and contact information for the conference organizers can be obtained from the conference web site at http://www.mast.queensu.ca/~ggsmith/Route81/index.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
I. Main objectives of the project.

Via the conference "Interactions between Commutative Algebra and Algebraic Geometry" and the follow-up conference "Interactions between Commutative Algebra and Algebraic Geometry, II", the main goals of this project are:

1. to bring together experts, young researchers, recent Ph.D.s and graduate students in the areas of Commutative Algebra and Algebraic Geometry, to gain better understanding of current research topics and advances in these fields,

2. to create an atmostphere to stimulate and foster research collaborations,

3. to help shape future research directions and highlight the work of researchers in the region.

II. What was accomplished under these goals?

1. Major Activities:

The conference "Interactions between Commutative Algebra and Algebraic Geometry" held at Queen's University, Kingston, Canada, on October 19-21, 2012. It started with a departmental colloquium delivered by Mike Stillman (Professor, Cornell University). The conference proceeded with the following lectures:

a) Juan Migliore (Professor, University of Notre Dame) - "Determinantal representation and subschemes of general plane curves.
b) Marvi Catalisano (Associate Professor, Universita di Genova) - "Higher secant varieties of classical projective varieties".
c) Enrico Carlini (Assistant Professor, Politecnico di Torino) - "Working with Tony".
d) Andrew Hoefel (Postdoc, Queen's University) - "Symbolic and regular powers of monomial ideals".
e) Susan Cooper (Assistant Professor, University of Central Michigan) - "The perplexing Hilbert functions of fat points".
f) Jaydeep Chipalkatti (Associate Professor, University of Manitoba) - "On the hexagrammum mysticum".
g) Eddy Campbell (Professor, University of New Brunswick) - "Recent developments in modular invariant theory".
h) Fabrizio Zanello (Associate Professor, Michigan Technological University) - "On the Hilbert function of a level algebra".
i) Francois Bergeron (Professor, Universite du Quebec a Montreal) - "Polarization, combinatorics and geometry".
j) Lorenzo Robbiano (Professor, Universita di Genova) - "Detecting hidden curves using algebraic schemes".

After all participant supports were paid for the conference, there was $9,900 remaining in the grant. Permission was given from Tulane University Sponsored Projects Administration and NSF Program Officer Tara Smith to spend the remaining funds in support of a follow-up conference entitled "Interactions between Commutative Algebra and Algebraic Geometry, II". The follow-up conference was held at Tulane University, New Orleans, LA, on September 28-29, 2013. Lectures given at this follow-up conference are:

a) Adam Van Tuyl (Professor, Lakehead University) - "The 2n conjecture".
b) Alexandra Seceleanu (Postdoc, University of Nebraska-Lincoln) - "Using ideal invariants to bound projective dimension".
c) Augustine O'Keefe (Postdoc, University of Kentucky) - "An algebraic study on Cameron-Walker graphs".
d) Juan Migliore (Professor, University of Notre Dame) - "On the weak Lefschetz property for artinian Gorenstein algebras of codimension 3".
e) Uwe Nagel (Professor, University of Kentucky) - "Constructing toric surfaces satisfying Laplace equations".
f) Thanh Vu (Graduate student, University of California, Berkeley) - "Periodicity of Betti numbers of monomial curves".
g) Zach Teitler (Assistant Professor, Boise State University) - "Direct sum decomposition of polynomials".
h) Jennifer Biermann (Visiting Assistant Professor, Mount Holyoke College) - "Generalized cover ideals and the persistence property".
i) Susan Cooper (Assistant Professor, University of Central Michigan) - "Monomial ideals, symbolic powers, and a polyhedron".
